title: Code Action provider called n times on a single key stroke
body:
I noticed today that my ESLint code action provider is called n times on every keystroke. This only seems to happen in a build version of VS Code. I couldn't reproduce this out of source. So I suspect a timing / debouncing issues. I debugged it in the built version and here is what is happening:

- in the test workspace this is happening the following LS provide diagnostics: tslint, TS and ESLint
- on a keystroke all three LS update the diagnostics
- this results to 3 calls to `_onMarkerChanges` here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/editor/contrib/codeAction/codeActionModel.ts#L45
- depending on the timeing these seem to get folded or not

The more general question for me is why the ESLint code action provider is called when TS or TSLint diagnostics change. I do already check if the diagnostics contain ESLint errors. However in the above example if the ESLint errors come in first then there are errors when the code action provider is triggered again on a TSLint or TS diagnostic change.

title: Allow to define the lifespan of an input variable value

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Currently, every time you run a command from task or launch, if it have an input, it would ask. It maybe useful if you can configure the life of the input variable value. 

Something like:

```
   {
      "id": "appName",
      "type": "promptString",
      "description": "The application or project name as defined in the angular.json file",
      "ask": [ALWAYS, ONCE, ONCE_PER_SESSION]
    }
```

- ask: ALWAYS This would be the default, as it's the current behavior. The value is not saved anywhere.
- ask: ONCE This would ask for the value just once, and then would store it somewhere in the working directory, or the active workspace.
- ask ONCE PER SESSION. This would ask for the value once, every time the windows opens, would save the variable in RAM and won't ask again until the windows has been restarted.

title: [feature request] Outline view: multi-key sort
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Currently (vscode 1.34), the items in the outline view can be sorted by:
* Position
* Name
* Type

It's great that I can select any sort key, but the problems is these sort keys are currently made exclusive, meaning that I cannot select 2 or more sort keys.

As a result one cannot sort the items by both Name and Type, like first by Type, then by Name. Additionally, if none of the sort options is selected, the items should be presented in their natural order, as if sorted by Position.

A mapping table between the proposed sort options and the old ones would be:

| Proposed | Old | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- |
| by Name | by Name | almost same, but with Position as implicit 2nd key |
| by Type | by Type | almost same, but with Position as implicit 2nd key |
| NONE | by Position | equivalent, i.e., remove by Position |
| by Name + Type | N/A | new, first by Type then by Name preferred |

By the way, when sorting by Type, it seems the methods are listed before the fields, why not the reverse? this is really a question though.

Thanks

title: Compute number of problems after filter

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Issue Type: Feature Request The number of problems is written next to the Problem tab (see screenshot) ![Screenshot from 2019-06-05 16-50-40](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15984272/58966251-3daa2500-87b2-11e9-9ab0-b2968f5317c1.png) It shows the number of problems before filtering them out. This is great if one uses the filter like this: > I have too many errors, I just want to look-up the one that interests me But this is not great if one uses the filter like me: > I have unwanted errors because of whatever reason, I will filter the _false positives_ out. In this example I will think there are 3 errors while there isn't any: ![Screenshot from 2019-06-05 16-51-50](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15984272/58966257-3edb5200-87b2-11e9-92a4-69dd8c9eefd7.png) In a perfect world there wouldn't be any false positives but the filter works perfectly for this. Could we have a setting like `problems.computeNumberAfterFilter`? Thank you
Version Info VS Code version: Code 1.34.0 (a622c65b2c713c890fcf4fbf07cf34049d5fe758, 2019-05-15T21:55:35.507Z) OS version: Linux x64 4.15.0-51-generic

title: Feature request: find: add a delete button (not replace with nothing)
body:
OK, so you're a programmer, and I'm a programmer, and we've been programming forever, and we know that to remove something, you find it and replace it with nothing. In sed or vim you'd do `s/something//g`. 

In vscode you'd do:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172594/58965453-8a88fe00-87a8-11e9-944b-94d9f1e3f9e5.png)

I was using this recently and remembered something: **replace with nothing is really weird for new programmers**.

> How do I remove a word?

> Oh you just replace it with nothing

> 🤨

I know it's not a common feature in code editors, but **new programmers could be helped by adding an 'x' botton that removes the thing being looked for**.

This would do the same thing as replace with nothing, but be more intuitive.

title: FreeBSD support - now that Electron is available
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Hello Devs,

Electron 4 was added to FreeBSD ports and pkg on May 28. Is it possible now to port VSCode to FreeBSD? It would be very much appreciated as there are very few decent GUI code editors on FreeBSD right now.

title: Debugging an extension steps into extensionHostProcess.js and then has poor performance
body: This may be related to https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/53414.. Sometimes when I'm debugging an extension and I press Step Into, it will step into the `extensionHostProcess.js` file. This file is huge and causes really bad performance (the syntax colouring goes wonky too - I don't know if that's related to the poor performance). I don't ever want to step into this file. If I'm stepping through my TS and pressing Step Into, it's probably because I expect it to skip VS Code's JS and just step into my own functions when they come up (this is faster than having to swap between pressing F10 and F11 when trying to get to the right place). I can't see any obvious way to prevent this (since https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/53414 seems like it was designed to do this). Is it possible? (I have `smartStep: true` in my launch config, though I think that's default now anyway).

title: Horizontal Scrolling Interferes with Vertical Scrolling on MacBook Pro
body: Issue Type: Bug ### Reproduce the Problem 1. On a MacBook Pro, create a file with at least one line that is longer than the width of the editor window. 2. Add a bunch of new lines until the file has a vertical scrollbar. ### Problem If a file in the editor is tall enough and wide enough to have both vertical and horizontal scrollbars, it is almost impossible to scroll vertically using the trackpad without also scrolling horizontally. This causes a jarring effect and makes it hard to visually track in the document while scrolling up or down. ### Expected Behavior When using the trackpad to scroll vertically, there should be no simultaneous horizontal scrolling (or at least there should be more inertia before horizontal scrolling starts). VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.35.0-insider (0284236851a94b116f468345f6e98688a737015d, 2019-05-31T21:28:16.350Z) OS version: Darwin x64 18.6.0

title: [json] Allow full glob filtering for fileMatch in json.schemas

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
This would be a variation on #44135
Currently in https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/f58c2f349207bda6f5ca4c010dd7f56c38ddb70e/.vscode/settings.json
Any of the example files match both the swagger
```json
        {
            "fileMatch":[
                "/**/specification/*.json"
            ],
            "url":"https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/autorest/master/schema/swagger-extensions.json"
        },
```
and the example file schema
```json
        {
            "fileMatch":[
                "/**/examples/*.json"
            ],
            "url":"https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/autorest/master/schema/example-schema.json"
        },
```
The current matching doesn't allow both schemas to not collide.
Tried some things that should probably be possible if a full glob pattern match would work
```json
        {
            "fileMatch":[
                "/**/specification/*/resource-manager/*/preview/*/*.json",
                "/**/specification/*/resource-manager/*/stable/*/*.json"
            ],
            "url":"https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/autorest/master/schema/swagger-extensions.json"
        },
```
Same issue trying for negation matches with `!` with the current parsing

title: Support object types for `TreeItem.contextValue`

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
This is a duplicate of #46236. That issue has been auto-closed, apparently due to inactivity, but I have more information about the scenario and am willing to offer a pull request.

I have an extension that contributes a treeview to the Test Explorer container. Each `TreeItem` represents a test, and different tests need different context menu items enabled based on properties of those tests. For example, some tests have expected output that can be compared with the actual output in a diff view, and some don't. Failed tests need an option to accept the new output as expected, but passed tests don't. The node for a test needs different options from the node for a test suite.

Today, I can sort of make this work by giving each `TreeItem` a `contextValue` string with a space-separated list of tags, and using regular expressions in my `when` condition to look for the interesting tags or lack thereof.

What I'd prefer is to specify an object as the value for `contextValue`, and be able to access individual properties of that object using `viewItem.propName`, similar to the existing support for `context.propName` that already exists.

Proposed changes:
- Change the type of `TreeItem.contextValue` to `any` (or some suitably restricted type that allows an object type)
- Within a `when` condition, `viewItem.propName` accesses the property named `propName` on `TreeItem.contextValue`, if `TreeItem.contextValue` is an object type.

If this sounds like a reasonable feature, I'm willing to contribute the PR to implement it.

title: Side Bar with Lists, Checkboxes, Text
body:
Currently, extension authors seem to be limited to TreeViews in the VSCode Side Bar. Correct me if I'm wrong.

Feature Request:
I'm developing an extension that requires **more diverse UI in the Side Bar**. Nothing complicated, just basic:
- lists
- checkboxes
- text (currently limited to a single TreeItem line with no formatting)

Notice that several of these requested items already exist in the side panel of core features which do not share the same limitations of extensions:

- lists in the extension view
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4660659/58682466-7d41be80-8325-11e9-9cca-64512fe66824.png)

- checkboxes in the debugger via a webviewlet
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4660659/58682376-263be980-8325-11e9-99d1-cd47ce4fe5d0.png)

A Side Bar that can only use TreeView's is extremely limiting. 

Is it possible to add non-TreeView UI to the Side Bar in current extensions? If so, can the documentation be amended in the "Extending Workbench" section to accomodate how? Happy to help contribute docs with some guidance.

If not, can I help contribute to VSCode in any way to help make any of the above functionality possible?

title: Add warning if closing a terminal with a running process

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I'm doing machine learning research, which often involves long running processes. If I run these in a bash shell (Ubuntu 18.04) and try and close the terminal I get a warning that I'm trying to close a terminal which contains a running process.

I don't get the same warning when I run a process in the vscode terminal, and there's been a number of times when I've accidentally closed either a terminal, or the whole vscode app and lost work. It would be nice if a (perhaps enabled with an option) warning to prevent this.

title: Improve directory appearance in search results
body: Issue Type: Feature Request The directory path displayed in search results can be hard to visually parse. For each result the path starts in a different horizontal location based on the length of the file name. It would be beneficial if the path formed a second column in the results (similar to how the result count is handled on the far right). Also, listing the workspace folder (which I've redacted in first the screenshot below) next to each result adds visual clutter, isn't very helpful, and seems to be inconsistent from a design perspective. The results are a tree structure so it's already well known which workspace folder the result belongs to. No other tree view that I can currently find seems to re-display the context of parent nodes. Current appearance: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/484784/58661264-4b583a00-82dc-11e9-9caf-577342d9f4c3.png) Desired appearance ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/484784/58661378-abe77700-82dc-11e9-8a0c-87408c9538e9.png) VS Code version: Code 1.34.0 (a622c65b2c713c890fcf4fbf07cf34049d5fe758, 2019-05-15T21:59:37.030Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16299

title: colorPresentation LSP request doesn't handle line numbers properly
body:
Issue Type: Bug If you use color picker multiple times without closing it, the range parameter for textDocument/colorPresentation doesn't have the line number updated, which breaks your code if the color thingie is more than a single line long. Problem isn't only with the CSS files. How to reproduce: - open CSS file - write this: ``` h1 { color: rgb(0, 0,255); } thisIsSomeCodeThatIDontWantDestroyed { } ``` - hover over rgb - change color three times (without leaving the picker) Result: ``` h1 { color: rgb(68, 68, 184)ntDestroyed { } ``` Expected result: ``` h1 { color: rgb(68, 68, 184); } thisIsSomeCodeThatIDontWantDestroyed { } ``` VS Code version: Code 1.34.0 (a622c65b2c713c890fcf4fbf07cf34049d5fe758, 2019-05-15T21:59:22.738Z) OS version: Darwin x64 18.2.0

title: Create a node-pty host process with flow control and event batching

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
As of around a year ago node-pty is launched directly from the renderer process, while this does mean ctrl+c is responsive it has several downsides:

- node-pty crashes will take down the entire window (https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/71966, https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/71789, https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/74181)
- Data events from node-pty seems to be blocked by the event loop, I suspect this is main the reason conpty is slow, it may also be slowing down non-Windows data flow too
- The remote case the connection can get overwhelmed by fast producing programs.

My proposal for these problems:

- Reintroduce terminalProcess to host node-pty, calling it nodePtyHostProcess is probably a better name, this protects the extension host and renderer from crashes
- Batch data events inside nodePtyHostProcess (https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/54093), reducing the amount of total events in favor of larger ones
- Introduce a flow control mechanism which ensures the pty does not get too far ahead of xterm.js. This is a little more tricky for the remote case, one idea is to send an ack every x bytes from the renderer and nodePtyHostProcess will pause if it hasn't received the yth last ack (x and y need to be experimented with and may depend on latency) (related https://github.com/xtermjs/xterm.js/pull/2122, https://github.com/microsoft/node-pty/pull/304)
